t: Mark 1
The Messiah’s Herald
The*p beginning of the gospel of Jesus Christ, the Son of God.
As it is written in Isaiah the prophet: See,*ipn I*i am*i sending*i my*i messenger*i ahead*i of*i you;*i he*iln will*i prepare*i your*i way.*i
A*iln voice*i of*i one*i crying*i out*i in*i the*i wilderness:*i Prepare*iln the*i way*i for*i the*i Lord;*i make*iln his*i paths*i straight!*i
John*p came baptizing in the wilderness and proclaiming a baptism of repentance for the forgiveness of sins.
The whole Judean countryside and all the people of Jerusalem were going out to him, and they were baptized by him in the Jordan River, confessing their sins.
John wore a camel-hair garment with a leather belt around his waist and ate locusts and wild honey.
He*p proclaimed, “One who is more powerful than I am is coming after me. I am not worthy to stoop down and untie the strap of his sandals.
I baptize you with water, but he will baptize you with the Holy Spirit.”
The Baptism of Jesus
In*p those days Jesus came from Nazareth in Galilee and was baptized in the Jordan by John.
As soon as he came up out of the water, he saw the heavens being torn open and the Spirit descending on him like a dove.
And a voice came from heaven: “You are my beloved Son; with you I am well-pleased.”
The Temptation of Jesus
Immediately*p the Spirit drove him into the wilderness.
He was in the wilderness forty days, being tempted by Satan. He was with the wild animals, and the angels were serving him.
Ministry in Galilee
After*p John was arrested, Jesus went to Galilee, proclaiming the good news of God:
“The*r time*r is*r fulfilled,*r and*r the*r kingdom*r of*r God*r has*r come*r near.*r Repent*r and*r believe*r the*r good*r news!”*r
The First Disciples
As*p he passed alongside the Sea of Galilee, he saw Simon and Andrew, Simon’s brother, casting a net into the sea- for they were fishermen.
“Follow*r me,”*r Jesus told them, “and*r I*r will*r make*r you*r fish*r for*r people.”*r
Immediately they left their nets and followed him.
Going on a little farther, he saw James the son of Zebedee and his brother John in a boat putting their nets in order.
Immediately he called them, and they left their father Zebedee in the boat with the hired men and followed him.
Driving Out an Unclean Spirit
They*p went into Capernaum, and right away he entered the synagogue on the Sabbath and began to teach.
They were astonished at his teaching because he was teaching them as one who had authority, and not like the scribes.
Just*p then a man with an unclean spirit was in their synagogue. He cried out,
“What do you have to do with us, Jesus of Nazareth? Have you come to destroy us? I know who you are - the Holy One of God!”
Jesus*p rebuked him saying, “Be*r silent,*r and*r come*r out*r of*r him!”*r
And the unclean spirit threw him into convulsions, shouted with a loud voice, and came out of him.
They*p were all amazed, and so they began to ask each other, “What is this? A new teaching with authority! He commands even the unclean spirits, and they obey him.”
At once the news about him spread throughout the entire vicinity of Galilee.
Healings at Capernaum
As*p soon as they left the synagogue, they went into Simon and Andrew’s house with James and John.
Simon’s mother-in-law was lying in bed with a fever, and they told him about her at once.
So he went to her, took her by the hand, and raised her up. The fever left her, and she began to serve them.
When*p evening came, after the sun had set, they brought to him all those who were sick and demon-possessed.
The whole town was assembled at the door,
and he healed many who were sick with various diseases and drove out many demons. And he would not permit the demons to speak, because they knew him.
Preaching in Galilee
Very*p early in the morning, while it was still dark, he got up, went out, and made his way to a deserted place; and there he was praying.
Simon and his companions searched for him,
and when they found him they said, “Everyone is looking for you.”
And*p he said to them, “Let’s*r go*r on*r to*r the*r neighboring*r villages*r so*r that*r I*r may*r preach*r there*r too.*r This*r is*r why*r I*r have*r come.”*r
A Man Cleansed
He*p went into all of Galilee, preaching in their synagogues and driving out demons.
Then a man with leprosy came to him and, on his knees, begged him, “If you are willing, you can make me clean.”
Moved with compassion, Jesus reached out his hand and touched him. “I*r am*r willing,”*r he told him. “Be*r made*r clean.”*r
Immediately the leprosy left him, and he was made clean.
Then he sternly warned him and sent him away at once,

telling him, “See*r that*r you*r say*r nothing*r to*r anyone;*r but*r go*r and*r show*r yourself*r to*r the*r priest,*r and*r offer*r what*r Moses*r commanded*r for*r your*r cleansing,*r as*r a*r testimony*r to*r them.”*r

Yet he went out and began to proclaim it widely and to spread the news, with the result that Jesus could no longer enter a town openly. But he was out in deserted places, and they came to him from everywhere.
Mark 2
The Son of Man Forgives and Heals
When*p he entered Capernaum again after some days, it was reported that he was at home.
So many people gathered together that there was no more room, not even in the doorway, and he was speaking the word to them.
They came to him bringing a paralytic, carried by four of them.
Since they were not able to bring him to Jesus because of the crowd, they removed the roof above him, and after digging through it, they lowered the mat on which the paralytic was lying.
Seeing their faith, Jesus told the paralytic, “Son,*r your*r sins*r are*r forgiven.”*r
But*p some of the scribes were sitting there, questioning in their hearts:
“Why does he speak like this? He’s blaspheming! Who can forgive sins but God alone?”
Right*p away Jesus perceived in his spirit that they were thinking like this within themselves and said to them, “Why*r are*r you*r thinking*r these*r things*r in*r your*r hearts?*r
Which*r is*r easier:*r to*r say*r to*r the*r paralytic,*r ‘Your*r sins*r are*r forgiven,’*r or*r to*r say,*r ‘Get*r up,*r take*r your*r mat,*r and*r walk’?*r
But*r so*r that*r you*r may*r know*r that*r the*r Son*r of*r Man*r has*r authority*r on*r earth*r to*r forgive*r sins”-*r he told the paralytic —
“I*r tell*r you:*r get*r up,*r take*r your*r mat,*r and*r go*r home.”*r
Immediately*p he got up, took the mat, and went out in front of everyone. As a result, they were all astounded and gave glory to God, saying, “We have never seen anything like this!”
The Call of Levi
Jesus*p went out again beside the sea. The whole crowd was coming to him, and he was teaching them.
Then, passing by, he saw Levi the son of Alphaeus sitting at the tax office, and he said to him, “Follow*r me,”*r and he got up and followed him.
While*p he was reclining at the table in Levi’s house, many tax collectors and sinners were eating with Jesus and his disciples, for there were many who were following him.
When the scribes who were Pharisees saw that he was eating with sinners and tax collectors, they asked his disciples, “Why does he eat with tax collectors and sinners?”

When*p Jesus heard this, he told them, “It*r is*r not*r those*r who*r are*r well*r who*r need*r a*r doctor,*r but*r those*r who*r are*r sick.*r I*r didn’t*r come*r to*r call*r the*r righteous,*r but*r sinners.”*r
A Question about Fasting
Now*p John’s disciples and the Pharisees were fasting. People came and asked him, “Why do John’s disciples and the Pharisees’ disciples fast, but your disciples do not fast?”

Jesus*p said to them, “The*r wedding*r guests*r cannot*r fast*r while*r the*r groom*r is*r with*r them,*r can*r they?*r As*r long*r as*r they*r have*r the*r groom*r with*r them,*r they*r cannot*r fast.*r
But*r the*r time*r will*r come*r when*r the*r groom*r will*r be*r taken*r away*r from*r them,*r and*r then*r they*r will*r fast*r on*r that*r day.*r
No*r one*r sews*r a*r patch*r of*r unshrunk*r cloth*r on*r an*r old*r garment.*r Otherwise,*r the*r new*r patch*r pulls*r away*r from*r the*r old*r cloth,*r and*r a*r worse*r tear*r is*r made.*r

And*r no*r one*r puts*r new*r wine*r into*r old*r wineskins.*r Otherwise,*r the*r wine*r will*r burst*r the*r skins,*r and*r the*r wine*r is*r lost*r as*r well*r as*r the*r skins.*r No,*r new*r wine*r is*r put*r into*r fresh*r wineskins.”*r
Lord of the Sabbath
On*p the Sabbath he was going through the grainfields, and his disciples began to make their way, picking some heads of grain.
The Pharisees said to him, “Look, why are they doing what is not lawful on the Sabbath?”
He*p said to them, “Have*r you*r never*r read*r what*r David*r and*r those*r who*r were*r with*r him*r did*r when*r he*r was*r in*r need*r and*r hungry—*r

how*r he*r entered*r the*r house*r of*r God*r in*r the*r time*r of*r Abiathar*r the*r high*r priest*r and*r ate*r the*r bread*r of*r the*r Presence*r — which*r is*r not*r lawful*r for*r anyone*r to*r eat*r except*r the*r priests*r — and*r also*r gave*r some*r to*r his*r companions?”*r
Then he told them, “The*r Sabbath*r was*r made*r for*r man*r and*r not*r man*r for*r the*r Sabbath.*r
So*r then,*r the*r Son*r of*r Man*r is*r Lord*r even*r of*r the*r Sabbath.”*r
Mark 3
Jesus*p entered the synagogue again, and a man was there who had a shriveled hand.
In order to accuse him, they were watching him closely to see whether he would heal him on the Sabbath.
He told the man with the shriveled hand, “Stand*r before*r us.”*r
Then he said to them, “Is*r it*r lawful*r to*r do*r good*r on*r the*r Sabbath*r or*r to*r do*r evil,*r to*r save*r life*r or*r to*r kill?”*r But they were silent.
After looking around at them with anger, he was grieved at the hardness of their hearts and told the man, “Stretch*r out*r your*r hand.”*r So he stretched it out, and his hand was restored.
Immediately the Pharisees went out and started plotting with the Herodians against him, how they might kill him.
Ministering to the Multitude
Jesus*p departed with his disciples to the sea, and a large crowd followed from Galilee, and a large crowd followed from Judea,
Jerusalem, Idumea, beyond the Jordan, and around Tyre and Sidon. The large crowd came to him because they heard about everything he was doing.
Then he told his disciples to have a small boat ready for him, so that the crowd wouldn’t crush him.
Since he had healed many, all who had diseases were pressing toward him to touch him.
Whenever the unclean spirits saw him, they fell down before him and cried out, “You are the Son of God!”
And he would strongly warn them not to make him known.
The Twelve Apostles
Jesus*p went up the mountain and summoned those he wanted, and they came to him.
He appointed twelve, whom he also named apostles, to be with him, to send them out to preach,
and to have authority to drive out demons.
He appointed the Twelve: To Simon, he gave the name Peter;
and to James the son of Zebedee, and to his brother John, he gave the name “Boanerges” (that is, “Sons of Thunder”);
Andrew; Philip and Bartholomew; Matthew and Thomas; James the son of Alphaeus, and Thaddaeus; Simon the Zealot,
and Judas Iscariot, who also betrayed him.
A House Divided
Jesus*p entered a house, and the crowd gathered again so that they were not even able to eat.
When his family heard this, they set out to restrain him, because they said, “He’s out of his mind.”
The*p scribes who had come down from Jerusalem said, “He is possessed by Beelzebul,” and, “He drives out demons by the ruler of the demons.”
So*p he summoned them and spoke to them in parables: “How*r can*r Satan*r drive*r out*r Satan?*r
If*r a*r kingdom*r is*r divided*r against*r itself,*r that*r kingdom*r cannot*r stand.*r
If*r a*r house*r is*r divided*r against*r itself,*r that*r house*r cannot*r stand.*r
And*r if*r Satan*r opposes*r himself*r and*r is*r divided,*r he*r cannot*r stand*r but*r is*r finished.*r
But*r no*r one*r can*r enter*r a*r strong*r man’s*r house*r and*r plunder*r his*r possessions*r unless*r he*r first*r ties*r up*r the*r strong*r man.*r Then*r he*r can*r plunder*r his*r house.*r
“Truly*rp I*r tell*r you,*r people*r will*r be*r forgiven*r for*r all*r sins*r and*r whatever*r blasphemies*r they*r utter.*r
But*r whoever*r blasphemes*r against*r the*r Holy*r Spirit*r never*r has*r forgiveness,*r but*r is*r guilty*r of*r an*r eternal*r sin”-*r
because they were saying, “He has an unclean spirit.”
True Relationships
His*p mother and his brothers came, and standing outside, they sent word to him and called him.
A crowd was sitting around him and told him, “Look, your mother, your brothers, and your sisters are outside asking for you.”
He*p replied to them, “Who*r are*r my*r mother*r and*r my*r brothers?”*r
Looking at those sitting in a circle around him, he said, “Here*r are*r my*r mother*r and*r my*r brothers!*r
Whoever*r does*r the*r will*r of*r God*r is*r my*r brother*r and*r sister*r and*r mother.”*r
Mark 4
The Parable of the Sower
Again*p he began to teach by the sea, and a very large crowd gathered around him. So he got into a boat on the sea and sat down, while the whole crowd was by the sea on the shore.
He taught them many things in parables, and in his teaching he said to them,
“Listen!*r Consider*r the*r sower*r who*r went*r out*r to*r sow.*r
As*r he*r sowed,*r some*r seed*r fell*r along*r the*r path,*r and*r the*r birds*r came*r and*r devoured*r it.*r
Other*r seed*r fell*r on*r rocky*r ground*r where*r it*r didn’t*r have*r much*r soil,*r and*r it*r grew*r up*r quickly,*r since*r the*r soil*r wasn’t*r deep.*r
When*r the*r sun*r came*r up,*r it*r was*r scorched,*r and*r since*r it*r had*r no*r root,*r it*r withered*r away.*r
Other*r seed*r fell*r among*r thorns,*r and*r the*r thorns*r came*r up*r and*r choked*r it,*r and*r it*r didn’t*r produce*r fruit.*r
Still*r other*r seed*r fell*r on*r good*r ground*r and*r it*r grew*r up,*r producing*r fruit*r that*r increased*r thirty,*r sixty,*r and*r a*r hundred*r times.”*r
Then he said, “Let*r anyone*r who*r has*r ears*r to*r hear*r listen.”*r
Why Jesus Used Parables
When*p he was alone, those around him with the Twelve asked him about the parables.
He answered them, “The*r secret*r of*r the*r kingdom*r of*r God*r has*r been*r given*r to*r you,*r but*r to*r those*r outside,*r everything*r comes*r in*r parables*r

so*r that*r they*irpn may*ir indeed*ir look,*ir and*irln yet*ir not*ir perceive;*ir they*irln may*ir indeed*ir listen,*ir and*irln yet*ir not*ir understand;*ir otherwise,*irln they*ir might*ir turn*ir back*ir and*irln be*ir forgiven.”*ir
The Parable of the Sower Explained
Then*p he said to them, “Don’t*r you*r understand*r this*r parable?*r How*r then*r will*r you*r understand*r all*r of*r the*r parables?*r
The*r sower*r sows*r the*r word.*r
Some*r are*r like*r the*r word*r sown*r on*r the*r path.*r When*r they*r hear,*r immediately*r Satan*r comes*r and*r takes*r away*r the*r word*r sown*r in*r them.*r
And*r others*r are*r like*r seed*r sown*r on*r rocky*r ground.*r When*r they*r hear*r the*r word,*r immediately*r they*r receive*r it*r with*r joy.*r
But*r they*r have*r no*r root;*r they*r are*r short-lived.*r When*r distress*r or*r persecution*r comes*r because*r of*r the*r word,*r they*r immediately*r fall*r away.*r
Others*r are*r like*r seed*r sown*r among*r thorns;*r these*r are*r the*r ones*r who*r hear*r the*r word,*r
but*r the*r worries*r of*r this*r age,*r the*r deceitfulness*r of*r wealth,*r and*r the*r desires*r for*r other*r things*r enter*r in*r and*r choke*r the*r word,*r and*r it*r becomes*r unfruitful.*r
And*r those*r like*r seed*r sown*r on*r good*r ground*r hear*r the*r word,*r welcome*r it,*r and*r produce*r fruit*r thirty,*r sixty,*r and*r a*r hundred*r times*r what*r was*r sown.”*r
Using Your Light
He*p also said to them, “Is*r a*r lamp*r brought*r in*r to*r be*r put*r under*r a*r basket*r or*r under*r a*r bed?*r Isn’t*r it*r to*r be*r put*r on*r a*r lampstand?*r
For*r there*r is*r nothing*r hidden*r that*r will*r not*r be*r revealed,*r and*r nothing*r concealed*r that*r will*r not*r be*r brought*r to*r light.*r
If*r anyone*r has*r ears*r to*r hear,*r let*r him*r listen.”*r
And he said to them, “Pay*r attention*r to*r what*r you*r hear.*r By*r the*r measure*r you*r use,*r it*r will*r be*r measured*r to*r you -*r and*r more*r will*r be*r added*r to*r you.*r
For*r whoever*r has,*r more*r will*r be*r given*r to*r him,*r and*r whoever*r does*r not*r have,*r even*r what*r he*r has*r will*r be*r taken*r away*r from*r him.”*r
The Parable of the Growing Seed
“The*rp kingdom*r of*r God*r is*r like*r this,”*r he said. “A*r man*r scatters*r seed*r on*r the*r ground.*r
He*r sleeps*r and*r rises*r night*r and*r day;*r the*r seed*r sprouts*r and*r grows,*r although*r he*r doesn’t*r know*r how.*r
The*r soil*r produces*r a*r crop*r by*r itself -*r first*r the*r blade,*r then*r the*r head,*r and*r then*r the*r full*r grain*r on*r the*r head.*r
As*r soon*r as*r the*r crop*r is*r ready,*r he*r sends*r for*r the*r sickle,*r because*r the*r harvest*r has*r come.”*r
The Parable of the Mustard Seed
And*p he said, “With*r what*r can*r we*r compare*r the*r kingdom*r of*r God,*r or*r what*r parable*r can*r we*r use*r to*r describe*r it?*r
It’s*r like*r a*r mustard*r seed*r that,*r when*r sown*r upon*r the*r soil,*r is*r the*r smallest*r of*r all*r the*r seeds*r on*r the*r ground.*r

And*r when*r sown,*r it*r comes*r up*r and*r grows*r taller*r than*r all*r the*r garden*r plants,*r and*r produces*r large*r branches,*r so*r that*r the*r birds*r of*r the*r sky*r can*r nest*r in*r its*r shade.”*r
Using Parables
He*p was speaking the word to them with many parables like these, as they were able to understand.
He did not speak to them without a parable. Privately, however, he explained everything to his own disciples.
Wind and Waves Obey Jesus
On*p that day, when evening had come, he told them, “Let’s*r cross*r over*r to*r the*r other*r side*r of*r the*r sea.”*r
So they left the crowd and took him along since he was in the boat. And other boats were with him.
A great windstorm arose, and the waves were breaking over the boat, so that the boat was already being swamped.
He was in the stern, sleeping on the cushion. So they woke him up and said to him, “Teacher! Don’t you care that we’re going to die?”
He*p got up, rebuked the wind, and said to the sea, “Silence!*r Be*r still!”*r The wind ceased, and there was a great calm.
Then he said to them, “Why*r are*r you*r afraid?*r Do*r you*r still*r have*r no*r faith?”*r
And*p they were terrified and asked one another, “Who then is this? Even the wind and the sea obey him!”
Mark 5
Demons Driven Out by Jesus
They*p came to the other side of the sea, to the region of the Gerasenes.
As soon as he got out of the boat, a man with an unclean spirit came out of the tombs and met him.
He lived in the tombs, and no one was able to restrain him anymore - not even with a chain-
because he often had been bound with shackles and chains, but had torn the chains apart and smashed the shackles. No one was strong enough to subdue him.
Night and day among the tombs and on the mountains, he was always crying out and cutting himself with stones.
When*p he saw Jesus from a distance, he ran and knelt down before him.
And he cried out with a loud voice, “What do you have to do with me, Jesus, Son of the Most High God? I beg you before God, don’t torment me!”
For he had told him, “Come*r out*r of*r the*r man,*r you*r unclean*r spirit!”*r
“What*rp is*r your*r name?”*r he asked him. “My*p name is Legion,” he answered him, “because we are many.”
And he begged him earnestly not to send them out of the region.
A*p large herd of pigs was there, feeding on the hillside.
The demons begged him, “Send us to the pigs, so that we may enter them.”
So he gave them permission, and the unclean spirits came out and entered the pigs. The herd of about two thousand rushed down the steep bank into the sea and drowned there.
The*p men who tended them ran off and reported it in the town and the countryside, and people went to see what had happened.
They came to Jesus and saw the man who had been demon-possessed, sitting there, dressed and in his right mind; and they were afraid.
Those who had seen it described to them what had happened to the demon-possessed man and told about the pigs.
Then they began to beg him to leave their region.
As*p he was getting into the boat, the man who had been demon-possessed begged him earnestly that he might remain with him.

Jesus did not let him but told him, “Go*r home*r to*r your*r own*r people,*r and*r report*r to*r them*r how*r much*r the*r Lord*r has*r done*r for*r you*r and*r how*r he*r has*r had*r mercy*r on*r you.”*r
So he went out and began to proclaim in the Decapolis how much Jesus had done for him, and they were all amazed.
A Girl Restored and a Woman Healed
When*p Jesus had crossed over again by boat to the other side, a large crowd gathered around him while he was by the sea.
One of the synagogue leaders, named Jairus, came, and when he saw Jesus, he fell at his feet
and begged him earnestly, “My little daughter is dying. Come and lay your hands on her so that she can get well and live.”
So Jesus went with him, and a large crowd was following and pressing against him.
Now*p a woman suffering from bleeding for twelve years
had endured much under many doctors. She had spent everything she had and was not helped at all. On the contrary, she became worse.
Having heard about Jesus, she came up behind him in the crowd and touched his clothing.
For she said, “If I just touch his clothes, I’ll be made well.”
Instantly her flow of blood ceased, and she sensed in her body that she was healed of her affliction.
Immediately*p Jesus realized that power had gone out from him. He turned around in the crowd and said, “Who*r touched*r my*r clothes?”*r
His*p disciples said to him, “You see the crowd pressing against you, and yet you say, ‘Who*r touched*r me?’”*r
But*p he was looking around to see who had done this.
The woman, with fear and trembling, knowing what had happened to her, came and fell down before him, and told him the whole truth.
“Daughter,”*r he said to her, “your*r faith*r has*r saved*r you.*r Go*r in*r peace*r and*r be*r healed*r from*r your*r affliction.”*r
While*p he was still speaking, people came from the synagogue leader’s house and said, “Your daughter is dead. Why bother the teacher anymore?”
When*p Jesus overheard what was said, he told the synagogue leader, “Don’t*r be*r afraid.*r Only*r believe.”*r
He did not let anyone accompany him except Peter, James, and John, James’s brother.
They came to the leader’s house, and he saw a commotion - people weeping and wailing loudly.
He went in and said to them, “Why*r are*r you*r making*r a*r commotion*r and*r weeping?*r The*r child*r is*r not*r dead*r but*r asleep.”*r
They laughed at him, but he put them all outside. He took the child’s father, mother, and those who were with him, and entered the place where the child was.
Then he took the child by the hand and said to her, “Talitha*r koum”*r (which is translated, “Little*r girl,*r I*r say*r to*r you,*r get*r up”).*r
Immediately the girl got up and began to walk. (She was twelve years old.) At this they were utterly astounded.
Then he gave them strict orders that no one should know about this and told them to give her something to eat.
Mark 6
Rejection at Nazareth
He*p left there and came to his hometown, and his disciples followed him.

When the Sabbath came, he began to teach in the synagogue, and many who heard him were astonished. “Where did this man get these things?” they said. “What is this wisdom that has been given to him, and how are these miracles performed by his hands?
Isn’t this the carpenter, the son of Mary, and the brother of James, Joses, Judas, and Simon? And aren’t his sisters here with us?” So they were offended by him.
Jesus*p said to them, “A*r prophet*r is*r not*r without*r honor*r except*r in*r his*r hometown,*r among*r his*r relatives,*r and*r in*r his*r household.”*r
He was not able to do a miracle there, except that he laid his hands on a few sick people and healed them.
And he was amazed at their unbelief. He was going around the villages teaching.
Commissioning the Twelve
He*p summoned the Twelve and began to send them out in pairs and gave them authority over unclean spirits.
